Award.AwardTitle: Expanding STEM Talent Through Upward Transfer: Factors Influencing Transfer in STEM Fields of Study from Two-Year to Four-Year Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Two-year institutions are essential components of the nation's education system and increasingly recognized as critically important in established and emerging areas of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). However, there is a limited body of research examining what influences student transfer from two-year colleges into STEM fields of study at four-year institutions. Drawing upon social cognitive career theory, the project will develop and refine a STEM transfer model that hypothesizes that STEM transfer is influenced by demographic factors, contextual factors, learning experiences in STEM, and motivational beliefs related to STEM learning and transfer. The four-year longitudinal mixed methods research project will investigate STEM transfer and will advance and test a model of postsecondary STEM pathways to the baccalaureate and careers in STEM or to alternative educational and occupational attainment in STEM. The research team will follow a cohort of 3,000 students beginning in STEM programs or courses required for STEM programs at two-year community and technical colleges in Wisconsin and study factors that facilitate or hinder their transfer into a STEM major at 4-year colleges and universities during the study period.

The research adopts an explanatory sequential mixed methods design in which the quantitative approach is dominant and is followed by a complementary qualitative approach. The quantitative phase will consist of collection and analysis of students' administrative records from participating institutions integrated with students' data from a new longitudinal survey on STEM transfer. To establish construct validity, the research team will perform exploratory factor analysis to identify the factor structure. This will be followed by a confirmatory factor analysis. Additional factor analyses will be ongoing as each wave of the survey data becomes available. Three waves of data collection will be conducted. Structural equation modeling (SEM) will be used to analyze the multivariate data and to test the theoretical framework. SEM defines latent and observed variables while testing the direct and indirect relationships among variables that are hypothesized. The interview and focus group sample will be purposively selected from survey participants. While specific selection criteria will depend on the analysis of the survey data, it is anticipated that a combination of intensity sampling, maximum variation sampling and/or homogenous sampling will be the most viable strategies to provide more depth and insight into the factors influencing STEM transfer as identified by quantitative findings. Deductively guided and inductively grounded data analyses will be utilized to discover common themes across interview and focus group qualitative data. The project will advance the knowledge base on STEM transfer and contribute to theory building in this important area of study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two-year colleges have emerged as critical players in training science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) professionals at the baccalaureate level through their transfer function. Although the majority of two-year college students majoring in STEM aspire to transfer to a four-year institution, a very small percentage actually do so. This raises questions as to how to best support and boost transfer in STEM toward cultivating a more diverse STEM workforce trained at the baccalaureate level and beyond.

The Expanding STEM Talent project was funded through the National Science Foundation's Division of Undergraduate Education to conduct a longitudinal mixed methods study to tackle this exact issue (see design visual attached). It followed 1,670 two-year college students starting in STEM programs or courses in a Midwestern state over the span of six years from 2014 to 2020. The first of its kind, the project aimed to provide systematic, robust empirical knowledge of the learning experiences, program features, and education policy and practices that chart a successful transfer pathway in STEM.

The project was grounded in the STEM Transfer Model, a new framework that the PI developed based on theory and prior literature to guide this study. This model captures individual, motivational, learning, contextual, and institutional elements that shape STEM transfer (see visual attached). This model also guided the original survey developed for the project, the Expanding STEM Talent survey. Numerous researchers and practitioners nationally have requested permission to use this framework and the survey for their own STEM transfer research and/or practical initiatives. Other tools created for the project included student interview questions, which offered further depth by asking students about their experiences along their STEM pathways. 

As the project came to its full fruition, its findings culminated in On My Own: The Challenge and Promise of Building Equitable STEM Transfer Pathways, authored by PI Xueli Wang and published by Harvard Education Press (April 2020). This book builds on the project's entire rich longitudinal dataset to document students' educational trajectories and experiences in regard to the prospect of STEM transfer. The book makes it clear: community college students represent a remarkable talent pool for baccalaureate STEM programs, yet the current STEM transfer system has yet to fully live up to its potential. Wang issues a call for action with concrete approaches and steps for policy and practice toward cultivating robust STEM transfer pathways. Since its release in April 2020, this book has received wide recognition among researchers, policy makers and practitioners. It has already been adopted in relevant graduate courses at several institutions.

Throughout the life of the project, emerging findings have also been widely shared or featured across a variety of local and national venues, appealing to communities of both researchers and practitioners. To date, project dissemination includes periodic sharing/presentations of the findings at the two-year institutions that served as research sites, 4 research/policy briefs and reports, 20 news articles, 36 national and local conference presentations, and 14 published peer-reviewed journal articles and volume chapters. Since April 2020, the culminating book: On My Own, has already been presented through 4 keynote addresses, 3 invited talks and lectures, 3 webinars (including NSF S-STEM Program: Building Equitable STEM Transfer Pathways for Community College Students), 1 podcast, and 2 blog posts. There are several dissemination engagements that have been postponed due to COVID-19, but will occur in the near future.

The project has also significantly contributed to research capacity building toward developing the next generation of STEM education researchers. Throughout the project, the PI has recruited and mentored 11 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral scholars from diverse backgrounds to gain on-the-ground research experiences. These individuals came from a range of academic areas, such as Educational Leadership and Policy, Educational Psychology, and Public Policy. All received extensive training and mentoring from the PI, assisted with various aspects of the project, presented at local and national conferences, and co-authored reports and peer-reviewed articles for publication.

The Expanding STEM Talent project, original and ambitious in scope, has fully achieved its potential to advance knowledge on STEM transfer through its guiding framework, informative findings, and broad and impactful dissemination of its research tools, data sources, and policy implications. Further, the project's wide range of development and training activities contribute to an enhanced capacity among STEM education researchers now and in the future. Taken together, the project has generated robust new knowledge on issues pertaining to STEM transfer, and equipped institutions and practitioners with policies and practices in better serving two-year students interested in STEM transfer. The project has gained traction in local and national discussions and efforts around expanding and diversifying participation in the STEM baccalaureate pathway through two-year colleges, continuing this important conversation in the years ahead.


Last Modified: 10/04/2020
Modified by: Xueli Wang
